rows: shell of any animal; abalone, etc.
ant, red ant (Pitkin t'idoq, only in one entry)
Merriam consistent with similar forms across nearly all dialects for bald eagle (Merriam; he has this form k'acet for “golden eagle” 56:69))

deh  “wings outstretched”; perhaps from *damhal “bat” with folk etymology
tule, rat-tail grass, needle grass (Merriam Scirpus sp., small tule 56:59; big round tule 56:123 (S. lacustris))

č (Schlichter) and c (Pitkin) are same sound; L is always lamda (my L) in Pitkin, in Schlichter she writes Lambda glottal (my L') for glottalized sound and barred l (my L) for the non-glottalized one.
Looks like a lot of other bird words; may have a sound-symbolism relationship to Shepherd's “bird” cognate
little black ant, tiny stink ant
bear, black or brown, all except grizzly
Shepherd 2005; Golla 1997:164 relates to Alsea su:Ln 'grizzly' and perhaps ultimately to words for “black”
must be an old compound; -as not the right vowel so not the derivational suffix, probably
Shepherd 2005; she assumes metathesis in P p'amalay
-met; but p'aLi probably part of a loan word
say “light, lamp”; saysay “glitter”; boloq “fragile, soft, delicate”
same word is in Yana c'uraadu (Sapir & Swadesh 1960); W word is NOT cognate with other Wintun forms so loan probable, although system is probably wider
California swallow, barn swallow; mud dauber bee; CHM >kēL-to-ne “cliff swallow” (L raised, underlined); at 56:69 has >kan-too'-nut Cliff swallow)
any tame or wild duck, coot
cottontail (CHM “brush rabbit” but cottontail at 56:99 McCloud dialect)
cottonwood, maple (CHM tar-rap' me 56:19, different word for maple)

k'ok “rafter”, but I think this is folk etymology of a Penutian flea word, look at Miwokan, -os has wrong vowel to be the usual suffix
Shepherd 2005; some forms changed on analogy with “old man” preventing full reconstruction
Shepherd 2005; identical form in Proto-Maidu, perhaps related to Yokutsan words

Shepherd 2005; a large areal group of very similar forms

on *kHi:l “thorn”, note also Utian *kil:i- “horn, antler” (which appears in “thorn” words too -- and W “thorn” is related to “horn” words.  A “Penutian” item?
moroq “to move, quiver” is a Wintun cognate

ground squirrel (CHM confirms at 56:67 in “Ono wintu, Wintu proper”)

little mountain snowbird, junco? (CHM confirms junco 56:11)
č'en only in this word, duk unknown. Probably etymologicall complex
pat “outside”; “the one from outside, from the wild”
č'ol (also root in sound word); čHoL “mountain”
woč.., opknot of bird.  A harmonizing vowel and -t derive many, many nouns from roots that sometimes appear nowhere else
yil “heavy” (the one who is heavy earth mover???)

red-tailed hawk (CHM confirms, consistent for all dialects e.g. 56:7, 39)
roadrunner (CHM pōm to'-hut 56:71 and elsewhere; pom “ground”, to'-hut “runner” -- a neologism? )
Not the Wintun form; looks like UA words! But a loan from Takic puypuy seems unlikely. May just be sound symbolic.
used for rheumatism when boiled up in a liquor (Pitkin 1985)
